metadata.title: Recent advances on 3D printing graphene-based composites

sections.text:
Nano Materials Science 1 (2019) 101–115
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Materials Science
journal homepage: www.keaipublishing.com/cn/journals/nano-materials-science/
Recent advances on 3D printing graphene-based composites
Haichang Guo, Ruicong Lv, Shulin Bai *
Department of Materials Science and Engineering, CAPT/HEDPS/LTCS, Key Laboratory of Polymer Chemistry and Physics of Ministry of Education, College of Engineering, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: 3D printing Graphene Composites
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: slbai@pku.edu.cn (S. Bai).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoms.2019.03.003 Received 27 March 2019; Accepted 19 April 2019 Available online 1 June 2019 2589-9651/© 2019 Chongqing University. Product (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).
A B S T R A C T
3D printing or additive manufacturing (AM) has revolutionized the way of manufacturing by designing complex structures in a customized feature which cannot be realized by traditional processing methods. Incoming materials are trying to adopt 3D printing techniques which directly fabricate sophisticated entities with multifunctionality like mechanical, electrical, thermal and magnetic properties etc. For the realization of advanced materials, 3D printing techniques are emerging from single material to composite materials manufacturing by simply introducing the nano- and micro-reinforcements with the matrix. In this review, we provide an outline of 3D printing graphene-based composites according to various AM techniques including fused deposition modeling (FDM), direct ink writing (DIW), stereolithography (SLA) and selective laser sintering (SLS). First a brief introduction of various AM techniques is given to get a basic understanding of the principles of 3D printing, and then the fabrication process, structural characteristics and applications of different 3D printing techniques for graphene-based composites are summarized. In addition, some effective simulation and characterization methods are also included. We hope that this review would clarify the potential of AM techniques for composite materials and can open new prospects for designing of novel materials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the 21st century, the rapid development of functional materials has put higher demands for manufacturing. Unlike traditional subtractive manufacturing processes like drilling, milling, sawing, broaching etc., 3D printing, also known as additive manufacturing (AM), can directly fabricate three-dimensional parts through the sequential layer stacking of materials, thus enabling almost infinite possibilities for rapid prototyping [1,2]. It has many advantages like near-complete design freedom, flexibility, design complexity and high sustainability. Almost every kind of materials such as metals, ceramics and polymer can be used as raw materials for 3D printing to fabricate various stereoscopic structures. Therefore, 3D printing covers a wide range of fields including biomedicine [3–5], mechanical engineering [6], aeronautics and astronautics [7], electronics [8,9] and integrated circuit.
Since the discovery of graphene in 2004 by Novoselov et al. [10], it has received unprecedented attention due to its excellent electric [11], mechanical [11] and thermal [12] properties. However, practical applications of graphene in industrial area are still limited. Because of commercial graphene's low quality [13], high cost and low materials compatibility, the properties of the as-synthesized graphene-based
ion and hosting by Elsevier B.V. o
composites are far from satisfactory [14]. Other 2D materials such as BN, MoS2, BP, Sb2Se3 etc. also suffer from a similar problem [15–17]. To fill the gap, it's a great demand to develop new fabrication method to facilitate the application of new materials [18]. By using less amount of materials, 3D printing can build complex structures with flexible design freedom, thus providing more possibilities for the quality manufactory of advanced materials.
Herein, we provide an overview of recent progress on 3D printing graphene-based composites. First, different AM principles and techniques are briefly illustrated to get a basic understanding of 3D printing. The fabrication process, structural characteristics and applications of different 3D printing techniques for graphene-based composites are then summarized intensely. In addition, we contribute a brief introduction of some effective simulation methods like numerical simulation, finite element analysis (FEA) and valuable characterization methods.

sections.heading: 2. Understanding of 3D printing process and principles
sections.text:
The rapid development of 3D printing technique has introducedmany new printing methods. More advanced concepts have been adopted in 3D printing to fabricate faster, cheaper, and smaller printing systems [19,
n behalf of KeAi. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license
20]. Generally, all the 3D printing methods follow a basic process of additive manufacturing [19,21]: (1) 3D modeling through CAD software, 3D scanner, or a photogrammetry procedure; (2) Digitalization of the 3D model by converting it into a STL file; (3) Converting the STL file data into a G-code file which contains the geometrical information of each 2D layer slicing from the 3D model; (4) Printing the materials in a layer-by-layer manner.
According to the way the 2D layers of material are deposited, 3D printing can be grouped into four main categories: (i) photopolymerization; (ii) extrusion; (iii) powder based; and (iv) lamination (Fig. 1) [19]. Photopolymerization depends on the ordered surface curing of photopolymer which is composed of photo-initiators, additives and reactive monomers/oligomers. Stereolithography (SLA), digital light processing (DLP), materials jetting (MJ) and continuous liquid interface production (CLIP) are four representative 3D printing methods of photopolymerization. SLA is based on singe laser beam with a scanner, while DLP is a layer projection method which utilizes a photomask or digital micromirror devices (DMD) to solidify each 2D layer [22,23]. CLIP through the use of oxygen-permeable membrane enables much higher speed as compared with common 3D printing machine [24,25]. MJ combines inkjet [26,27] technique and UV (ultraviolet) curing process together to print various novel materials. Particularly, the promising technique MPP (multi-photon polymerization) [28,29] which is cable of solidifying the photopolymer at any position of the polymer bath can achieve sub-100 nm spatial resolution by the use of ultrafast laser. The second technique named extrusion-based 3D printing is the most common 3D printing technology due to its simplicity and availability of machines. By controlling the three dimensional movement of the nozzle, liquid state or semi-molten materials are directly deposited to the platform according to the model design. Fused deposition modeling (FDM) [30] creates 3D objects using thermoplastic polymers filaments as raw materials, while direct ink writing (DIW) [31] relies on a high viscosity ink to maintain its shape. Various ink materials like ceramics [32], plastics, food and living cells [33] can be used for DIW. Rapid freezing prototyping (RFP) like DIW, directly uses water as the “ink” but relies on low temperature freezing rather than viscosity to shape the “ink”. Though extrusion-based 3D printing technique has so many advantages like low cost, extreme versatility and easy availability, but it also suffers from some problems such as low resolution, unsatisfactory mechanical
Fig. 1. Classification of differe
properties and limited printing speed for industrial application [34]. The third technique aiming at powder rapid prototyping is a very promising technique for large scale industrial use because it is the primary technique for metal 3D printing [35]. This method first builds a powder (particle size between 50 and 100 μm) bath like SLA, then uses laser or adhesive to bind the powder to construct a three-dimensional entity. Selective laser sintering (SLS) [36,37] and selective laser melting (SLM) are two typical methods of powder-based technique. A roller or a squeegee is necessary to maintain a successive thin layer supply of powder materials onto the building platform. The difference between SLS and SLM is that SLS sinters the powder particle below the melting temperature while SLM reaches the melting temperature. Compared with SLS, SLM binds powder particles in a complete molten state without any addition of binder powder [38]. So SLM has higher compactness and better comprehensive properties than SLS. Another method named binder jetting (BJ) precisely deposits liquid glue inks onto the powder bed, which relies on capillary force to bind powder particle together. The binding energy for BJ is relatively lower, which leads to lower mechanical properties but fast printing speed compared with SLS and SLM. To avoid explosion of powder particles, a guarded environment is very essential for this technique. The last technique is lamination-based 3D printing technique. This method is also known as laminated object manufacturing (LOM) [39]. Various laminated sheets like paper, metal or plastic can employ this method. Generally, sheet materials with adhesive covered on their surface are loaded on a stage and then undergo a laser cutting process to define every 2D layer profile. Every time after cutting, a hot pressing process will be executed to enhance the bonding strength of each layer. Especially for metal sheets printing, ultrasonic curing (UC) is an effective method for the layer-layer combination which can bond two layers together below the half melting point of the metal.
To get a deep understanding of 3D printing, we should consider it from mass and energy aspects. 3D printing can be seen as a machine controlled assembly process where input energy and mass in a wellorganized manner. In fact, according to the ASTM (American Society for Testing Materials) standards, all the AM techniques can be classified into seven groups [21]: Material extrusion, material jetting, powder bed fusion, binder jetting, sheet lamination, vat photopolymerization and direct energy deposition. These categories are more detailed but all the techniques are similar to the categories presented in the previous
nt 3D printing techniques.
paragraph. For every 2D layer construction, the mass (m) and energy (W) interaction is δ(mW) ¼ mδW þ Wδm [21]. Energy variation (δW) process mainly includes material extrusion and material jetting which remains a constant mass flow in printing process. Powder bed fusion, binder jetting, sheet lamination and vat photopolymerization, direct energy deposition can be classified into mass variation (δm) process with fixed energy in Watt (W). Direct energy deposition is both energy and material variation
process. The energy and mass variation will have a strong influence on the printing speed and resolution.
3D printing techniques are emerging from single-material to multimaterial printing [40–42]. Many new techniques or concepts are introduced to create faster, cheaper and smaller printing systems. Based on the above understanding of 3D printing, we can conclude that:
(1). Different materials are bound to match different 3D printing techniques to realize optimal printing results. 3D printing process should never be seen as a standalone process. On the contrary, it should be an integral part of manufacturing which can match well with the functionality of materials such as mechanical, electrical and thermal properties. (2). High precision mass and energy control is wanted to achieve higher printing quality of 3D printing. Available materials, resolution and printing speed are three basic factors to decide the printing quality. Exquisite control of mass (precise movement control of platform) and energy (thermal, laser, mechanical, electrical and magnetic control) variation will greatly promote the development of 3D printing techniques.
For graphene-based composites, extrusion-based 3D printing technique is a well-known method because it is so convenient to transfer the as-synthesized graphene oxide (GO) solution to a 3D printing machine thus realizing a final configuration building. Many interesting interactions between graphene and laser are observed in laser-based 3D printing techniques. More details about these different fabrication process will be illustrated in the following section.

sections.heading: 3. 3D printing techniques for graphene-based composites
sections.text:
DIW, FDM, SLA and SLS are four typical AM techniques for the fabrication of graphene-based composites. In fact, there exist strong
nsion with PLG (polylactide-co-glycolide) polymer solution in a graded solvent ntial biomedical and electronics applications. Reproduced with permission [48].
relationships among AM techniques, structural characteristics and applications for 3D printing graphene-based composites as shown in Fig. 2. Foam structure is easy to form because of the inevitable voids formation during 3D printing process. The post-treatment of graphene such as freeze-drying or sintering also leads to the pore formation. Due to the large surface area and good electrical conductivity, 3D-printed graphene foam structure shows great potential in the energy storage field. Alignment of graphene sheets or polymer matrix is a common phenomenon in extrusion-based 3D printing techniques [42,43], which results in distinguished anisotropic mechanical, electrical and thermal properties. Rational design of these properties contributes to a wide application of graphene-based composites including structural composites, electrical and thermal management. The hierarchical structure can be achieved by an exquisite control of materials structure and printing structure. In particular, based on the unique light, heat or moisture response characteristics of the materials, some interesting shape-morphing systems can be developed [44–46]. It is noted that some related carbonmaterials such as carbon nanotube (CNT), carbon fiber (CF) and graphite are also included in this section. Specifically, we will pay attention to the structure-property-application relationships for different AM techniques in each part.

sections.heading: 3.1. Direct ink writing (DIW)
sections.text:
DIW is an extrusion-based 3D printing technique which involves the deposition of a liquid material ink that rapidly solidifies upon extrusion. For a smooth printing, the ink must possess enough modulus to retain its shape after being extruded. Usually, high viscosity ink has better shaping ability but higher risk of nozzle clogging. So an exquisite ink formulation
to achieve high viscosity ink with shear thinning behavior is the essential point for DIW [31]. Recently, many composite inks have been developed for multifunctional applications. Graphene-based inks with improved electrical, mechanical and biological properties can offer enhanced functionality for a wide range of 3D printing applications [47]. Jakus et al. [48] successfully demonstrated a 3D printable graphene (3DG) composite consisting of majority graphene and minority polylactide-co-glycolide for electronic and biomedical applications. A simple schematic of the fabrication of 3DG is shown in Fig. 3 [48]. PLG (polylactide-co-glycolide) and graphene powder were mixed in dichloromethane (DCM), a kind of highly volatile solvent. During extrusion, rapid evaporation of DCM ensured a self-supporting filament which would not deform after deposition. Then based on the user design of the 3D model, the ink was loaded into the 3D BioPlotter (EnvisionTEC GmbH, Germany) to get a final scaffold structure for various applications. By efficiently evaporating the solvent, a very high loading of 60 vol% of graphene could be achieved by this method [48].
It is interesting that a net effect referred to the filament microstructure with flakes oriented along the fiber surface occurred during the extrusion. The mechanism of shear force induced graphene flake alignment was shown in Fig. 4a [48]. From the SEM images, graphene flakes aligned in the exterior of the filament but stacked within the filament (Fig. 4b and c) [48], which exhibited an obvious anisotropic distribution. Orientation angle measurement of graphene flakes also demonstrated the net effect (Fig. 4d and e) [48]. The as printed 3DG sheets were flexible and could be rolled into various complex 3D forms (Fig. 4f) [48].
Very recently, Jiang et al. [49] printed an ultralight graphene aerogel microlattice using a facile ion-induced gelation method. Different from previous shaping methods, the authors demonstrated that a trace
) SEM images revealed that graphene flakes align along the exterior of the fibers oss-sectional view of the 3DG fiber and the corresponding histogram. (f) High oduced with permission [48]. Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society.
addition of Ca2þ into the GO ink could convert the GO sol to printable gel ink due to the coordination interaction of Ca2þ. Based on the computer design, a variety of 3D structure could be printed by using a robotic deposition device (Fig. 5a) [49]. It is emphasized that the characterization of rheological properties of GO inks is very essential for a smooth printing process. The viscosity of GO inks decreased with shear stress which identified the shear-thinning behavior of non-Newtonian fluid (Fig. 5b) [49]. With the adding of Ca2þ ions, GO ink showedmuch higher viscosity with one order of magnitude higher than that of pure GO solution. Besides, a sharp decrease of the modulus (G0 and G0 0) was observed in Fig. 5c, which indicated that the ink could smoothly go
through the nozzle (G0 0 dominated) and restored the modulus after being extruded (G0 dominated). The effect of angular frequency and Ca2þ concentration was shown in Fig. 5d and e [49], respectively. In another work, Zhu et al. [50] added hydrophilic fumed silica powder, GNPs, and R-F solution into the as-prepared GO solution to make an extrudable GO-based composite ink (Fig. 6a) [50]. The gelation process was controlled by the resorcinol formaldehyde (R-F) solution according to the organic sol-gel chemistry. The 3D-printed structure showed ordered macropores and large surfaces (Fig. 6b–g) [50]. Furthermore, it was lightweight, highly conductive and exhibited super compressibility (up to 90% compressive strain). Moreover, Young's
rolattices. (b) Morphology and structure of graphene aerogels. Scale bars, 5 mm ht 2015, Macmillan Publishers Limited.
moduli had an order of magnitude improvement over bulk graphene materials. When the as-printed structure was assembled into a quasi-solid state symmetric supercapacitor, it showed a very good rate capability with a remarkable 90% capacitance retention when current density increased from 0.5 to 10 A g 1 [51]..
Furthermore, nanometer size resolution of graphene materials could be realized by a high-precision liquid deposition method. Kim et al. [52] first reported 3D-printed nanostructures composed entirely of graphene. In this work, a meniscus-guided growth method was adopted to write freestanding reduced graphene oxide (rGO) nanowires without any supporting materials (Fig. 7a) [52]. When the micropipette filled with GO suspension moved close to the substrate, a meniscus would form at the tip of the micropipette. Due to the very small open diameter (1–2 μm) of the micropipette, the water would evaporate very fast which led to the solidifying of the GO suspension by pulling the micropipette. Then through the control of a triaxial mobile platform with a positioning accuracy of 250 nm, various freestanding graphene structures could be
printed with ca. 100 nm resolution, ranging from straight wires, bridges, suspended junctions to woven structures (Fig. 7b) [52]. The GO nanowires were held together by van der Waals forces because no coagulation agents were added in GO ink. By controlling the pipette pulling rate, the GO wire radius could be regulated from several hundred nanometers to one hundred nanometers (Fig. 7c) [52]. In fact, this method is very similar with ink jetting which is widely investigated in microelectronics field [53–55].
To sum up, accessory additives like polymers [56], inorganic nanoparticles [57] in high content or ion cross linker [49] like Ca2þ can be utilized to adjust the rheological behaviors of GO inks. DCM is a common solvent used to concentrate the as-prepared solution [58,59]. Many soft and flexible graphene foam structures can be synthesized by DIW [60]. These structures show a great potential in energy storage field due to their large surface area, highly electrical conductivity and lightweight features. Moreover, some interesting soft sensors [61] and robots [62] can also be developed by DIW.

sections.heading: 3.2. Fused deposition modeling (FDM)
sections.text:
FDM is a very common 3D printing technique which melts and extrudes thermoplastic filaments to form the final 3D objects. Through adding different fillers into the filaments, this technique can be easily expanded to various composites materials printing [41,63]. Wei et al. [64] first demonstrated the printability of graphene composite using FDM method. GO and ABS were first dissolved in NMP solution to get a good dispersion between graphene and ABS (Fig. 8a–e) [64]. After the reduction of GO, G/ABS powder was precipitated from the solution (Fig. 8f and g) [64]. Then the obtained GO/ABS powder was loaded into an extruder to fabricate the standard 1.75mm filaments (Fig. 8h) [64] for FDM printing. By carefully controlling the printing temperature and printing parameter, the authors successfully printed various memorable symbols with freestanding structure (Fig. 8i) [64]. Maximum content of graphene at 7.4 wt% could be achieved by using this method. It is worthy to note that solution mixing is an easy and convenient method for the dispersion of graphene which enables a very good homogeneity from the molecular aspect. Besides, melt blending [65] which depends on a certain machine like two screw extruder is also an important method for the fabrication of graphene-based composites.
Compared with DIW, FDM can directly print freestanding structure without further modification/ex-situ curing step. By adding conductive carbon materials liking graphene, graphite, CNT and carbon black into the filaments, this printing technology exhibits as a versatile conductive platform for energy storage devices [63]. Maurel et al. [66] used DCM as the solvent to dissolve PLA and mixed it with graphite to fabricate graphite/PLA composite. An elaboration process is shown in Fig. 9a [66]. The composite was extruded and printed as the anode material for lithium battery with a very high graphite loading of 60–70wt%. Various amounts of plasticizers such as propylene carbonate, poly (ethylene glycol) dimethyl and acetyl tributyl citrate were added into the filament to increase the flexibility of the filament. Furthermore, the addition of conductive additives such as carbon nanofibers (CNF) and carbon black Timcal Super-P (CSP) also had a great impact on the electrical and electrochemical performance of the printed materials. Though the as-printed graphite anode disc contained so many polymer components in it, its reversible capacity could reach 200mAh g 1 of active material at current density of 18.6 mA g 1 (C/20) after 6 cycles. In another study, Foo et al. [67] fabricated 3D printed electrodes (3DEs) made from graphene-based filament which was purchased from Black Magic, while 3DE/Au electrode was made by sputtering a layer of gold onto it (Fig. 9b and c) [67]. FESEM images noticed a thin layer of gold on the surface of the electrode (Fig. 9d and e) [67]. A solid-state supercapacitor with a multilayered structure was then assembled with PPy/rGO composites deposited on the 3DE/Au surface via an in-situ electrochemical polymerization method (Fig. 9f) [67]. This solid-state supercapacitor exhibited a good capacitance performance with a specific capacitance of 98.37 Fg-1. Besides, the as-assembled photoelectrochemical (PEC) sensor provided a photocurrent response at ~724.1 μA and lower detection limit compared with indium-doped tin oxide (ITO) or fuorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass electrode.
Based on the above discussions, it is easy to find that the key point of FDM technique is the fabrication of thermoplastic composite filament. For graphene-based composites, solvent mixing and melt compounding are two typical methods to get graphene filled polymer composites [68, 69]. But in some cases, surface coating of polymer filaments is in high
Fig. 9. Typical examples of FDM printed carbon materials (graphite, carbon black an fabrication process of the 3D printed negative electrode disc filled with high content Society. (b,c) A similar work showing the optical images of the 3D printing process electrode and corresponding magnified cross-sectional area. (f) Schematic illustrat Copyright 2018, Nature publishing group.
demand to enhance the welding strength between successive filament traces [70]. Recently, Sweeney et al. [71] reported a locally induced microwave heating (LIRF) method to efficiently weld 3D-printed thermoplastic interfaces by applying CNT-loaded coatings to PLA filament. In this work, the author first dissolved CNT in chloroform to get good dispersion of CNT. Then a bath coating process was employed to achieve a thin conformal coating of CNTs on the exterior of the feedstock PLA filament (Fig. 10a) [71]. Optical images showed that CNTs only exist on the surface of the filaments (Fig. 10b) [71]. Interior filling of CNTwas not wanted because it would lead to a uniform bulk heating when the microwave was conducted, which may result in a structure deformation. The CNT coating ensured a locally interface heating when the printed parts were subjected to a microwave field. Then polymer diffusion and chain entanglement would occur (Fig. 10c) [71] whichmeant an increase of fracture strength. The mechanical test revealed that the fracture strength of 3D-printed PLA coupons was increased by 275% when CNT coatings and LIRFwelding were applied (Fig. 10d and e) [71]. In fact, this coating method can be expanded to a wide range of microwave responsive materials. Graphene is a very good candidate which has been demonstrated with promising microwave absorption properties for real application [72]. Furthermore, to make a denser structure, other different field-assisted methods such as sonication, electrical and magnetic field etc. [73] can also be considered to regulate the interface properties of the printing parts, which holds great potential to improve the overall properties of 3D printing objects.
For the application of FDM printed graphene composites, the anisotropies [74] and voids elimination are two key issues which depend on the accurate control of printing parameters such as temperature, extrusion output, printing speed, and printing path [75]. The microstructure control of graphene is very critical for highly thermally conductive composites [76–78]. Different printing path could lead to the discriminative thermal conductivity of graphite/modified PA6 [79]. A high through-plane thermal conductivity at 5.5 Wm 1K 1 could be achieved with graphite flakes vertically oriented along the through-plane direction. Two different printing paths, one is flat-3D printing (FP) which went through an orthorhombic path (Fig. 11a and b) [79] and the other was
d graphene) filled composites filaments for energy storage devices. (a) A typical graphite. Reprinted with permission [66]. Copyright 2018, American Chemical and the as-printed 3D printed electrode (3DE). (d,e) FESEM image of 3DE/Au ion of solid-state supercapacitor fabrication. Reprinted with permission [67].
stand-3D printing (SP) which went in a parallel direction (Fig. 11c) [79], were set in Cura software. It could be observed that lots of voids with a size at ~10 μm existed in FP sample with a random distribution (Fig. 11d and e) [79]. However, in SP sample, voids existed in a parallel direction (Fig. 11f and g) [79]. For heat dissipation, voids are thermal insulator which hinders the efficient heat conduction. Therefore, SP samples resulted in a much higher thermal conductivity than FP samples due to a better voids distribution and the aforementioned graphene orientation (Fig. 11h) [79]. Anisotropic thermal and mechanical properties were also found in polyamide 12/graphene nanoplatelets composite [80]. Two different printing paths were controlled with the computer software (Fig. 11i) [80]. Due to the alignment of graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) (Fig. 11j) [80], the as-printed composite parts showed a much increased thermal conductivity (1.12W/mK) and elastic modulus (2251.7MPa) when the GNPs content was 6 wt%.
In another work, Gnanasekaran et al. [81] demonstrated the printability of CNT- and graphene-filled polybutylene terephthalate (PBT) composites. Solution mixing method was employed to fabricate the CNT/PBT or G/PBT composite powder with isopropanol as the compatible solvent. Optical image of the filaments and printed films were shown in Fig. 11k,l,n,o [81]. It is noted that the unstable extrusion of two-screw extruder leads to the inferior quality of the filaments (Fig. 11k,n) [81]. SEM image of the PBT/CNT and PBT/G monolayer revealed an obvious orientation of the filaments due to the printing path control (Fig. 11m,p) [81]. Percolation phenomenon and multi-materials printing were also investigated in this article.

sections.heading: 3.3. Stereolithography (SLA)
sections.text:
SLA is the first employed technique of 3D printing which uses a laser to cure photopolymer with a layer-by-layer manner [19,82]. Based on the principle of photo curing, now many new methods like DLP, CLIP and 2 PP (two-photon polymerization) etc. have been developed. Two essential issues should be considered for SLA-based composites: (1) Rapid solidification of by light initiated polymerization, which requests a fast light responsive composite resin system; (2) Sufficient low viscosity to allow for the dipping of resin layer, which determines a low graphene content and homogeneous filler distribution. Compared with extrusion-based techniques, a high resolution can be achieved by using SLA-based techniques. Recently, Hensleigh et al. [83] reported a complex micro-architected graphene (MAG) aerogels based on the projection microstereolithography (PmSL) technique. Fig. 12 [83] showed the schematic of the “XGO” resin synthesis. GOwas first crosslinked to form a hydrogel monolith and then dispersed by sonication. The addition of acrylates and photoinitiator created the ‘‘XGO resin” which represented the crosslinked structure of GO. The photo-activated graphene oxide resin could be precisely patterned by light into any desirable shape with 3D spatial features sizes of ~10 μm (Fig. 13a and b) [83], which showed a much higher resolution compared with extrusion-based techniques with large feature sizes (>100 μm). And the pore size of the structure was on the order of 60 nm, which exhibited a large surface area with an order of magnitude higher than previously reported graphene lattices [84]. Typical characteristics of graphene could be seen from TEM images
(Fig. 13c and d) [83] and Raman Spectroscopy (Fig. 13e) [83]. Besides, SEM energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) indicated that GO was successfully reduced with the elimination of the majority of the acrylate (Fig. 13f) [83]. These high-resolution, intricate structures showed a great potential in energy storage and conversion, separations, and catalysis.
Very recent work was conducted by Chiappone et al. [85] in which
the authors demonstrated the effect of in situ reduction of GO for a wider application of DLP printed GO composites. A water-soluble photopolymer PEO-acrylates was used as the matrix to disperse GO solution. After DLP process, the as-printed structure was exposed to UV (ultraviolet) light with different power to investigate the in situ reduction effect of GO. It was observed that the common UV post-treatment process
which was usually for polymer curing has an in situ reduction effect of GO when the GO content was at 0.3–0.5 wt%. As a result, the reduction effects led to a more rigid structure and enabledmuch functionality of the printed graphene-based composites. Very recently, Wang et al. [86] reported a graphene-doped resin target fabricated via a similar process based on commercial SLA machine. A small amount of graphene powder (0.1–2wt%) could act as an inherent laser absorber and ionization promoter, which resulted in the direct analysis of samples without adding
matrix for functional spectrometry devices. A more accurate SLA-based printing method named 3D direct laser writing or two-photon lithography process is a promising method for micro-nano 3D printing of complex structure with high resolution. A representative work [87] was published in 2016 in which a glassy carbon nanolattice which approached the theoretical strength of glassy carbon was successfully synthesized. The authors utilized a sophisticated 3D-DLW machine Photonic Professional, Nanoscribe GmbH to print the
teeny polymeric microarchitectures. A photoresist IP-Dip (Nanoscribe GmbH) was chosen as the raw materials for 3D printing. After printing, a precise pyrolysis process consisting of a two pre-baking step was executed to decompose the majority part of the polymer and carbonize the rest part. Finally, a carbon nanolattice with single strut shorter than 1 μm and strut diameter of 200 nm was fabricated. The as-printed nanolattice has a great impact beyond the field of lightweight mechanical metamaterials.

sections.heading: 3.4. Selective laser sintering (SLS)
sections.text:
SLS is a kind of powder-based 3D printing technique which sinters a successive thin layer powder with the aid of a high energized laser to build final 3D objects. The common method to print graphene-based composites is by homogeneously mixing graphene powder with the matrix powder, which could be achieved by mechanical or melt mixing. Recently, Sha et al. [88] developed a template method to print 3D graphene foams (GF) with SLS. First, they prepared the Ni/sucrose mixture powder with a solution mixing method. Sucrose was used as the carbon source and Ni as the catalyst and template for graphene growth. Then by manually placing themixture of Ni and sucrose onto a platform after laser radiation of each layer, a 3D GF would form during the repeated process. Finally followed by Ni etching, purification and critical point drying, a freestanding 3D GF was obtained (Fig. 14a and b) [88]. The 3D printed GF consisting of high-quality multilayered graphene had a large porosity of ~99.3% and very low density of ~0.015 g cm 3. Compared with traditional CVD or template-based pyrolysis method, this 3D printed graphene form owned controllable pore structures, high mechanical strength and capability to be free-standing. Besides, by using different carbon precursors, various 3D carbon composite materials including 3D printed rebar graphene and N-/S-doped GF could be produced. Other than template-based method, direct mixing of GO and hydroxyapatite (Hap) was also demonstrated to be an easy process to enhance the mechanical strength of the composite materials [89].
Other than template method which relies on situ growth of graphene, surface coating is a very common and effective method for the composite powder synthesis. Very recently, Yuan et al. [90] successfully fabricated the MWCNT/polymer composites through SLS. By softening and activating the surfaces of the PA12 and PU powder at 90 C and 70 C for 30min respectively, sodium cholate hydrate (SC) modified CNT solution was added into the powder suspension. After precipitation and drying, the CNT coated polymeric powders were obtained. A two-phase segregated structure would form due to the core-shell structure of the composite powder (Fig. 15) [90]. The surface layer of CNT could behave as heat absorbers to enhance light energy absorption. Using a SLS machine (EOS P395 model from EOS GmbH, Germany), a lot of CNT reinforced composites part could be printed (Fig. 16a–e) [90]. It was observed that
s-CNT/PA12 exhibited a rigid nature (Fig. 16h) but s-CNT/PU presented a good flexibility (Fig. 16g) [90]. At a very small loading of CNTs (<1wt %), the as-printed composites exhibit significant improvements of the electrical conductivity, which approached to 10 5 and 10 4 S/cm for PA12 and PU composites (0.5 wt% CNT), respectively (Fig. 16f) [90]. Another impressive work [91] which related to PA12 coated on carbon fiber presented a similar two-phase structure and the as-printed products exhibited much better mechanical properties due to the enhancement of the short carbon fiber.

sections.heading: 4.1. Simulation
sections.text:
The combination of 3D printing and simulation is very necessary for the structure design. Without simulation, the results given by pure experiment may be not convincing enough, and sometimes it's not clear what should be done next. By introducing simulation methods in an experiment, it is easy for us to understand the underlying mechanisms of 3D printing process, predict the properties of the composites and optimize the printing parameters. For example, shear force induced fiber alignment is a common phenomenon during the extrusion process for DIW and FDM. But it is hard to observe or demonstrate this phenomenon using experimental method. With the aid of numerical simulation, Lewicki et al. [92] unlocked the alignment process of carbon fiber during microextrusion of DIW process. After selecting a specific calculated domain of the model of the nozzle (Fig. 17a–d) [92], a time-scale evolution of fiber orientation could be clearly seen from the simulation results which were based on the Distributed Lagrange Multiplier (DLM) technique [93]. Other simulation methods like FEA can also be used to
analyze the extrusion process during 3D printing, which gives us a better understanding of the extrusion mechanism. Some critical reviews about the extrusion process can refer to Ref. [94]. For extrusion-based techniques, simulation methods based on fluid mechanics have a great influence on the optimization of the printing process. Besides, the mechanical, electrical and thermal behavior of the as-printed materials can also be analyzed by using finite element analysis (FEA). Roman-Manso et al. [95] built a core/rim structure FEA model to effectively analyze the anisotropic electrical conductivity of the as-printed graphene/SiC scaffolds using DIW method. It was found that the longitudinal conductivity and the transverse electrical conductivity of the printed scaffold varied a lot from each other (Fig. 17e) [95]. The traditional model could not precisely explain this anisotropic characteristic. With the introduction of a thin layer on the surface of the filament (Fig. 17f) [95], the modified model could provide a correct description of general trends of the anisotropic conductivity. FEA method also appears to be an effective tool for mechanical analysis. Recently, Raneya et al. [96] reported a damage-tolerant composite with programmable mechanics by using a rotational printing nozzle. 2D strain fields distribution (Fig. 17g–i) [96] and fiber distribution images (Fig. 17j and k) [96] showed a high degree of consistency of FEM and experimental results. Therefore, both FEA and experimental results demonstrated the programmable fiber alignment and strain localization. Furthermore, thermal properties can also be analyzed using FEA method. To sum up, materials composition, filler distribution, filler-matrix interface and anisotropic properties are several critical factors for a more accurate simulation.

sections.heading: 4.2. Characterization
sections.text:
The rapid development of 3D printing has introduced many new
characterization methods to monitor the fabrication process, test product quality and guide newmaterials design. In this part, we will put emphasis on 3D micro-CT and WAXS (wide angle X-Ray scattering) for composite materials. Micro CT is a method to build a virtual 3D model of the given sample without harming the object. This technology uses X-rays to create cross-section of each layer and integrate them together to form a 3D image. It appears to be a very useful tool to detect layer structure including voids and filler distribution. Yuan et al. [90] conducted a high resolution micro-CT scanning to observe the pores distribution of the s-CNT/PU composite. It could be observed that the pores held a percentage up to 21.89% of the total volume (Fig. 18a and b) [90]. The cross-sections of X-Y and X-Z planes showed that the interlayer space exhibited higher porosity than the inner layer matrix (Fig. 18c and d) [90]. So it was easy to find that the high porosity led to the low thermal conductivity of the final products. Furthermore, BET (Brunauer, Emmett and Teller) method can also be used to characterize the pore distribution which is a common phenomenon during printing process [97]. Especially for graphene-based composites, 3D confocal Raman imaging can give a powerful demonstration of graphene distribution [98,99].
Besides filler distribution and pores characterization, polymer matrix characterization should also be considered. The “distribution” of polymer chains or crystallinity characterization can be executed by X-ray diffraction. Specifically, WAXS is an effective method to observe the polymer crystal orientation. The orientation of liquid crystal phase is an interesting phenomenon in 3D printing. Recently, Gantenbein et al. [100] clearly illustrated the hierarchical orientation of the thermotropic LCPs using FDM. X-ray diffraction measurements confirmed a higher fraction of oriented polymers in thinner samples. Besides, Kotikian et al. [101] printed a liquid crystal elastomeric actuator with spatially programmed nematic order using DIW. Polarized optical microscopy (POM) images and representative WAXS patterns confirmed that liquid crystal elastomer (LCE) samples printed at 50 C showed distinct crystallographic orientation due to both shear and extensional flow force. To sum up, polymer crystallographic orientation can have a great influence on the final properties of the materials [102]. A combination of WAXS and 3D printing can have great potential to unlock the underlying
mechanisms of the 3D printing materials. By tailoring the local filler and polymer crystal distribution with the aid of advanced simulation and characterization methods, 3D printing can enable infinite possibilities for freely design and realize structures without the restrictions of currents manufacturing methods.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and prospects
sections.text: In this review, we presented the outlines related to 3D printing graphene-based composites according to various 3D printing techniques. The relationships between fabrication process, structural characteristics and applications of graphene-based composites were summarized intensely. Furthermore, some important simulation and characterization methods for 3D printing were also introduced. 3D printing should never be seen as a standalone process for manufacturing. It strongly depends on the intrinsic properties of different materials. In case of graphene-based composites, GO-based solution is the most convenient starting materials for 3D printing. So, DIW was the largest investigated method for graphene-based composites. But this technique usually needed a complex post-treatment to evaporate the solvent. Compared with DIW, SLA seems to be a more promising method due to its high resolution and the unique interaction between graphene and laser. For these two methods, the asprinted objects usually appear as soft or porous structures, which determines their potential applications in energy and biological fields. When graphene powder is used as the feedback material for composites prototyping, SLS/SLM (metal or polymer matrix) and FDM (polymer matrix) are two better methods which can fabricate structural 3D objects with multifunctionality (eg. thermal, electrical properties). Graphene orientation and the interface between filler and matrix should be taken into more considerations. Voids elimination is also a critical issue for high performance composite materials. New 3D printing techniques continue to evolve, however, all of these methods should follow the basic relationship between materials characteristics and processing method. In the near future, new 3D printing concepts, versatile 3D printing materials, more accurate processing methods and multiple applications are expected to boost the development of 3D printing.

referenceMentions.context: , 3D printing, also known as additive manufacturing (AM), can directly fabricate three-dimensional parts through the sequential layer stacking of materials, thus enabling almost infinite possibilities for rapid prototyping [1,2].

, 3D printing, also known as additive manufacturing (AM), can directly fabricate three-dimensional parts through the sequential layer stacking of materials, thus enabling almost infinite possibilities for rapid prototyping [1,2].

Generally, all the 3D printing methods follow a basic process of additive manufacturing [19,21]: (1) 3D modeling through CAD software, 3D scanner, or a photogrammetry procedure; (2) Digitalization of the 3D model by converting it into a STL file; (3) Converting the STL file data into a G-code file which contains the geometrical information of each 2D layer slicing from the 3D model; (4) Printing the materials in a layer-by-layer manner.

metadata.abstractText: 3D printing or additive manufacturing (AM) has revolutionized the way of manufacturing by designing complex structures in a customized feature which cannot be realized by traditional processing methods. Incoming materials are trying to adopt 3D printing techniques which directly fabricate sophisticated entities with multifunctionality like mechanical, electrical, thermal and magnetic properties etc. For the realization of advanced materials, 3D printing techniques are emerging from single material to composite materials manufacturing by simply introducing the nanoand micro-reinforcements with the matrix. In this review, we provide an outline of 3D printing graphene-based composites according to various AM techniques including fused deposition modeling (FDM), direct ink writing (DIW), stereolithography (SLA) and selective laser sintering (SLS). First a brief introduction of various AM techniques is given to get a basic understanding of the principles of 3D printing, and then the fabrication process, structural characteristics and applications of different 3D printing techniques for graphene-based composites are summarized. In addition, some effective simulation and characterization methods are also included. We hope that this review would clarify the potential of AM techniques for composite materials and can open new prospects for designing of novel materials.
